This is not Python code. It's a Python implementation of a cypher. The algorithm is described in the article, but if you don't want to read it, the basic idea is that you take a word, and take every letter in it and put it in a big matrix. Then you take a second word, and put all the letters in that word in the matrix. Then you take the first letter of the first word, and put it in the first row of the matrix, and the first letter of the second word, and put it in the second row of the matrix. Then you compare every letter in the second word with every letter in the first word, and if any of them are equal, you have a match.

It's not really a "cipher" as such. It's more of a cryptographic hash function.

Python's regular expression engine is very powerful and a little bit tricky. It is not uncommon for a programmer to write a regular expression that is not what he/she intended.  For example, if one wants to match a word that has a hyphen, one might write a regular expression that looks like this:

(?<=\w+)(?=(\w+)?)

This is a regular expression that matches any word that has a hyphen. But it does not match "cat", "bat", "mat", "batmat", "matbat", "batmatmat", "matbatmatbat", "matbatmatbatmat", or "matbatmatbatmatbat".

Note that this is a trivial case of a more general problem. You can't know if a string is a substring of another string unless you know the length of both. This is a general problem in string matching, and it is NP-complete.

There are two ways to solve this problem:
1) If you can't solve it in linear time, you can always try to solve it in exponential time. Just try all possible combinations of letters (where the length of the first string is n and the length of the second is m).
2) You can try to solve it in linear time using dynamic programming.
